Graphical abstract Molybdenum catalysts have been industrially recognized for decades for liquid phase epoxidation, which is an important chemical reaction process, since epoxides are used for many industrial applications. In this work, molybdenum oxide hybrid catalysts, prepared by a reflux hydrolysis methodology, performed effectively as heterogeneous catalysts or reaction-induced self-separating catalysts under mild reaction conditions; in the two cases, the catalyst separation and reuse are facilitated. Specifically, catalysts with the general formula [MoO3(L)], possessing polymeric chain-like (L = 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine (1)) or oligomeric (L = 4,4′-dinonyl-2,2′-bipyridine (2)) structures comprising corner-sharing {MoO4N2} units, were synthesized and characterized by various complementary techniques (ATR FT-IR, Raman, 13C{1H} CP MAS NMR spectroscopy, PXRD, SEM, TGA, elemental analysis, ICP-OES and N2 sorption isotherms). Small chemical differences in the organic synthesis precursor had important structure directing effects on the type of hybrid material formed. The hybrids promoted olefin epoxidation with H2O2 or tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant. For example, 1 catalyzed the conversion of biobased olefins (70 °C) and lignin-based isoeugenol (50 °C) with TBHP to useful bioproducts, in heterogeneous phase, leading to an epoxide yield of 100 % for DL-limonene (3:1 M molar ratio of 1,2-epoxy-p-menth-8-ene to 1,2:8,9-diepoxy-p-menthane), 81 % epoxide yield for fatty acid methyl esters, and 80 % Licarin A selectivity at 40 % isoeugenol conversion. For dienes (DL-limonene, methyl linoleate), kinetic modelling studies suggested that the formation of the monoepoxides was faster than that of diepoxides, accounting for enhanced monoepoxide selectivity. Keywords Molybdenum Bipyridine ligands Epoxidation Bioolefins Reaction-induced self-separating catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic oxidation reaction processes lead to a plethora of important commodities and fine chemicals in the chemical industry [1–5]. The cost-effectiveness and sustainability of these processes rely heavily on the development of efficient and selective catalysts to enhance the overall productivity while minimizing waste generation and energy consumption. Additionally, the straightforward separation of the catalyst from the reaction products is desirable to avoid energy intensive downstream separation and purification processes. Different approaches to facilitate product separation have been reported, such as using a hydrogen sulfate surfactant to homogenize terpenes in an aqueous reaction medium for epoxidation by dimethyldioxirane (generated in situ from acetone and a potassium monopersulfate triple salt) [6]. Despite such developments, heterogeneous catalysts may be preferred over homogeneous ones, e.g., homogeneous catalytic industrial processes of propene epoxidation with hydroperoxide oxidants were followed by heterogeneous catalytic epoxidation processes [1,2,7]. Heterogeneous catalysis has been explored in various perspectives for epoxidations. As examples of recent developments, tin-containing faujasite zeolites [8] and commercial magnesium oxide [9] promoted limonene epoxidation with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and titanium nanotube-supported dioxomolybdenum complexes (MoO2L, L = bipyridine or pyrazole-type ligands) promoted the photocatalytic epoxidation of terpenes with O2 [10]. Attractive alternatives to heterogeneous catalysts are reaction-induced self-separating (RISS) catalysts, which emerged at the turn of the millennium with the pioneering work by Li et al. [11], and Dioumaev and Bullock [12]. Like conventional heterogeneous catalysts, RISS catalysts can be recovered as solid catalysts at the end of the reaction process, under ambient conditions and without adding solvents or precipitation agents [13]. An important difference between heterogeneous and RISS catalysts is that the latter respond to a trigger (associated with the reaction, e.g., the presence of oxidant) that causes the starting solid catalyst to change to a soluble catalyst during the reaction (i.e., the active species are soluble), and afterwards the soluble catalyst reverts to the solid catalyst via self-precipitation. The RISS concept has been demonstrated for several catalytic processes, e.g., related to the chemical valorization of biomass and hydrogen production, amongst others. RISS catalysts containing molybdenum were successfully explored for olefin epoxidation [13]. For example, the RISS polymeric hybrid catalyst [MoO3(1,2,4-triazole)0.5] led to 98 % conversion of cis-cyclooctene (Cy) and 100 % epoxide selectivity, at 70 °C/24 h [14], which compares well with other polymeric hybrids (tested under comparable reaction conditions) that acted either as homogeneous catalysts (e.g., Cy conversions of 81 % for [MoO3(Hpto)]·H2O (Hpto = 5-(2-pyridyl-1-oxide)tetrazole) [15] and 86 % for [MoO3(4,4′-bipy)0.5] (4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine) [16], using H2O2 as oxidant) or as heterogeneous catalysts (e.g., >99 % Cy conversion for [MoO3(Hpytz)] (Hpytz = 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole) [17] and [(Mo2O6)(4,4′-bipy)] [18], using tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant). The present work describes two molybdenum oxide/bipyridine catalysts for liquid phase oxidation, under relatively mild conditions, that display different catalytic features (RISS, heterogeneous or homogeneous) depending on the catalyst/oxidant system. For catalyst synthesis, a convenient reflux hydrolysis method starting from mononuclear [MoO2Cl2(L)] precursors (L = 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine (DMB) or 4,4′-dinonyl-2,2′-bipyridine (DNB)) was used to obtain compounds with a general formula of [MoO3(L)] and either polymeric (L = DMB (1)) or oligomeric (L = DNB (2)) structures comprising corner-sharing [MoO2(μ2-O)2(L)] units. An assessment of the catalytic features of 1 and 2 was made with Cy as a model substrate, H2O2 or TBHP as oxidant, at 70 °C (and 60, 80 and 90 °C for the catalyst/TBHP systems). The studies were extended to the conversion of substrates associated with different components of biomass, namely extractives such as fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) and limonene (one of the most common naturally occurring terpenes [19]), and lignin-based isoeugenol. Kinetic modeling studies led to mechanistic insights into olefin epoxidations. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Catalyst synthesis and characterization The two catalysts of the present work were obtained by hydrolysis of the freshly prepared complexes [MoO2Cl2(L)] (L = DMB or DNB) in refluxing water (Scheme 1 ). Elemental analyses (CHN) of the resultant off-white solids indicated an empirical formula of [MoO3(L)] for both products (L = DMB (1), DNB (2)). Compounds 1 and 2 are insoluble in water, acetone, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, hexane, and diethyl ether. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns showed the presence of microcrystalline phases (Fig. 1 ). The particle morphologies observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were needle-like for 1 and irregular plate-like for 2 (Fig. 2 a and f). Hybrids 1 and 2 possessed specific surface areas of 107 m2/g and 91 m2/g, respectively, and mesopore size distributions in the range of 2–13 nm and 2–18 nm, respectively. The PXRD pattern for 1 matches a simulated diffractogram calculated using the crystal structure data reported for the one-dimensional (1D) polymeric hybrid [MoO3(DMB)], which has a chain-like structure built from corner-sharing [MoO2(μ2-O)2(DMB)] units (Scheme 1) [21]. The isolation of this 1D hybrid by the reflux hydrolysis method is notable for two reasons. First, compound 1 had only previously been obtained by the hydrothermal reaction between MoO3, DMB and water at 150 °C for 5 d [21]. Second, this is the first example where the reflux hydrolysis method, starting from [MoO2Cl2(L)] precursors, leads to this kind of 1D polymeric hybrid with corner-sharing {MoO4N2} octahedra. The other known compounds in this family, namely with L = 2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bipy) [22–25], 5′-carboxy-[2,2′-bipyridine]-5-carboxylate (cbpc) [26] and 2,2′-biimidazole [27,28], were prepared by either a hydrothermal route (from MoO3, L and water at 150–180 °C) or (only for L = 2,2′-bipy) the oxidative decarbonylation of molybdenum carbonyl precursor complexes [23–25]. The hydrolysis of other complexes of the type [MoO2Cl2(L)] has led to hybrid materials with more complex molybdenum oxide substructures, e.g., 1D polymers ∞ 1[Mo2O6(HpypzA)] (HpypzA = [3-(pyridinium-2-yl)-1H-pyrazol-1-yl]acetate) and ∞ 1[Mo3O9(pzpy)] (pzpy = 2-[3(5)-pyrazolyl]pyridine) [29,30], and the composite material {[MoO3(2,2′-bipy)][MoO3(H2O)]} n comprising [MoO3(2,2′-bipy)] n and [MoO3(H2O)] n chains interconnected through hydrogen bonds [31]. The FT-IR spectrum of 1 exhibits strong and sharp bands at 885 and 908 cm−1 assigned to ν(MoO) from cis-[MoO2]2+ units, and a broad, intense band at 676 cm−1 attributed to ν(MoOMo) (Fig. 3 ). The 1D polymers [MoO3(L)] (L = 2,2′-bipy, cbpc) exhibit similar sets of MoO stretching vibrations at ∼640 (bd), 883 and 915 cm−1 for L = 2,2′-bipy, and ∼576 (bd), 901 and 922 cm−1 for L = cbpc [23,26]. The presence of N,N-bidentate coordinated DMB ligands in 1 is supported by the shift of the strong pyridyl ring stretching absorption band from 1591 cm−1 for the free ligand to 1617 cm−1 for 1. The PXRD pattern of 2 was tentatively indexed in the triclinic system with space group P−1 (full details, including Pawley whole-powder-pattern fitting, are given in the Supplementary data, Fig. S1). A search in the ICDD PDF-5+ database did not lead to any match with an existing and known phase. Based on the chemical composition and vibrational spectroscopy data, tentative proposals may be made for the structure of 2. Like compound 1, the pyridyl ring stretching absorption for the ligand DNB shifts (in the IR spectra) from 1595 cm−1 for the free ligand to 1612 cm−1 for 2, consistent with bidentate coordination of DNB to Mo atoms (Fig. 3). In contrast to 1, [MoO3(2,2′-bipy)] and (DMA)[MoO3(cbpc)]·nH2O (DMA = dimethylammonium), 2 does not display a broad and intense absorption in the range of 500–700 cm−1. On the other hand, a very strong and relatively sharp band is observed at 762 cm−1, which is in the range (ca. 700–800 cm−1) typically associated with ν(MoOMo) vibrations for dinuclear or oligomeric oxo-bridged MoVI complexes. Two previously reported complexes that have the empirical formula of [MoO3(L)] are the dinuclear complex [Mo2O6(DBB)2] (DBB = 4,4′-di-tert-butyl-2,2′-bipyridine) containing a dioxo-bridged {MoO2(μ2-O)2MoO2} core [32], and the metallamacrocyclic tetranuclear complex [Mo4O12(pzpy)4] containing an eight membered ring of alternating molybdenum and oxygen centers [33,34]. The IR-active ν(MoOMo) stretching vibration for these two complexes leads to strong bands at 777 and 774 cm−1, respectively, similar to that observed for 2. In the region of 850–950 cm−1 where ν(MoO) absorption bands are found, compound 2 displays three strong bands at 876, 888 and 903 cm−1. While one of these bands could be due to DNB (as the free ligand shows a medium-intensity band at 901 cm−1), we assume that at least two are due to asymmetric and symmetric ν(MoO) vibrations arising from cis-[MoO2]2+ units. This fits with the Raman spectrum which shows a very strong band at 913 cm−1 [ν sym(MoO)] and a medium-intensity band at 869 cm−1 [ν asym(MoO)] (Fig. S4 in the Supplementary data). Hence, we propose that 2 may have a dinuclear structure like [Mo2O6(DBB)2] or a tetranuclear structure like [Mo4O12(pzpy)4], with a definitive identification not yet being possible (Scheme 1). Compounds 1 and 2 were further characterized by 13C{1H} CP MAS NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 4 ). Concerning the pyridyl ring carbon resonances of the free ligands in the range 115–160 ppm, DMB displays 4 signals (with the more intense one at 148.9 ppm being due to overlapping C4/C4′ and C6/C6′ resonances) and DNB displays 5 signals. This indicates that the pairs of chemically equivalent carbon atoms (Cn/Cn′) are crystallographically equivalent in the solid-state. Accordingly, DMB and DNB exhibit single methyl group resonances at 19.7 ppm and 16.0 ppm, respectively, and each of the eight pairs of chemically equivalent CH2 groups of DNB give rise to single resonances that are either resolved or overlap with another CH2 signal. The spectra of 1 and 2 show an increase in the number of resolved pyridyl carbon and CH2/CH3 resonances with respect to the free ligands, indicating that in the solid-state the molybdenum oxide/bipyridine compounds contain more than one crystallographically unique DMB/DNB ligand and/or at least one DMB/DNB ligand that has crystallographically distinct pyridyl (Cn/Cn′) and CH2/CH3 carbons. In the X-ray crystal structure of 1 [21], there is one crystallographically unique DMB ligand, with all carbon atoms of this ligand being crystallographically distinct. Hence, the observation of two resolved CH3 resonances for 1 (Fig. 4b) agrees with the reported crystal structure. The 13C{1H} CP MAS NMR spectrum of 2 displays two resolved methyl resonances at 13.9 and 14.7 ppm, and ten signals can be distinguished in the aromatic region (including two pairs of overlapping resonances), indicating that the crystal structure contains either two crystallographically unique DNB ligands (with each one possessing equivalent 4-nonylpyridine groups) or one unique DNB ligand that has crystallographically distinct 4-nonylpyridine groups, in analogy with that present in the crystal structure of 1. The latter scenario is probably more likely and could be compatible with either of the proposed dinuclear and tetranuclear structures represented in Scheme 1. The thermal stability of compounds 1 and 2 was investigated by TGA under air (Fig. 5 ). The onset temperature of decomposition is about 250 °C for both compounds. A succession of overlapping weight loss events is then observed up to 480 °C for 1 and 565 °C for 2, attributed to the decomposition of the organic ligand DMB or DNB, and the formation of MoO3. The residual masses at this plateau (44.3 % for 1 and 25.4 % for 2) are consistent with the initial composition of [MoO3(L)] (calcd for MoO3: 43.9 % for [MoO3(DMB)] and 26.0 % for [MoO3(DNB)]). For both compounds, the TGA curves show the sublimation of MoO3 above 700 °C. 2.2 Catalytic epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene Compounds 1 and 2 were studied as catalysts for liquid phase oxidation systems. The selected oxidants were TBHP and H2O2, partly because they are relatively ecofriendly (the respective coproducts are tert-butanol and water), readily available (used in industrial processes), and tert-butanol can be repurposed [1,35]. Compounds 1 and 2 promoted the epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene (Cy) with TBHP or H2O2 as oxidant, leading to cyclooctene oxide (CyO) in 100 % selectivity, at 70 °C (the carbon balance closed at 100 %). Without catalyst or without oxidant, olefin conversion was negligible, indicating that the simultaneous presence of molybdenum sites and oxidant was required to trigger the epoxidation reaction. This is consistent with several mechanistic studies for molybdenum-catalyzed epoxidation of olefins with hydroperoxide oxidants (ROOH, R = H or alkyl) [36–40]. Specifically, the interaction between the metal center, acting as a Lewis acid, and the oxidant molecule leads to an active oxidizing species which is responsible for the oxygen atom transfer to the olefin. The latter step may involve the nucleophilic attack of the olefin at an electrophilic oxygen atom (e.g., of a moiety of the type {MoOOR} present in the active oxidizing species), leading to the desired epoxide product and ROH (the coproduct of ROOH consumption). 2.2.1 Catalytic features with TBHP The epoxidation of Cy with TBHP in the presence of 1 gave 81 % and 100 % CyO yield at 6 h and 24 h, respectively (Fig. 6 , Table 1 ). The hybrid catalyst led to very good oxidant consumption efficiency, i.e., iodometric titration showed that the amount of TBHP consumed at 6 h was approximately equal to the amount of CyO formed, and after 24 h the oxidant decomposition was only 9 % (Fig. S7). The reaction medium was a heterogeneous mixture consisting of a white solid suspended in a colorless liquid phase. The solid catalyst was easily separated and reused after simple washing and drying operations. The recovered catalyst performed steadily for five consecutive 24 h-batch runs at 70 °C (Fig. 7 A). Specifically, the initial activity was in the range of 112–131 mmol gcat −1 h−1, initial turnover frequency (TOF) was 30–35 mol molMo −1 h−1, and the epoxidation reaction reached completion in all runs. A leaching test based on hot filtration of the reaction mixture at 2 h resulted in no signification increment in olefin conversion after removal of the solid catalyst from the liquid phase (Fig. 6). These results suggest that 1 exhibits heterogeneous catalytic features. Consistently, ICP-OES of the liquid phase indicated negligible metal leaching (less than 1 % of the initial amount of molybdenum). Accordingly, the PXRD patterns (Fig. 8 A), SEM images (needle-like particles, Fig. 2a and b) and ATR FT-IR spectra (Fig. 8B) of the original and recovered solids do not show significant differences, suggesting that 1 is structurally, morphologically, and chemically stable under the catalytic reaction conditions employed. Increasing the temperature enhanced the reaction kinetics; e.g., Cy conversion at 1 h increased from 16 % at 60 °C to 86 % at 90 °C (Figs. 6 and S10). Catalyst 1 was reused and performed relatively steadily for five consecutive 4 h-batch runs at 90 °C (Fig. 7B); initial activity and TOF were in the range 280–313 mmol gcat −1 h−1 and 74–84 mol molMo −1 h−1, respectively, and the reaction reached completion in all runs. As-prepared 1 and the recovered solids (1-TBHP-90C-runi) exhibited comparable needle-like morphologies (Fig. 2a and c), PXRD patterns (Fig. 8A) and ATR FT-IR spectra (Fig. 8B), further supporting the structural robustness of the catalyst. A pseudo homogeneous kinetic model considering irreversible, first order reactions was developed for 1/Cy/TBHP (described in Section 4.5, Scheme S1), which fitted reasonably well the experimental data at different temperatures (60, 70, 80 and 90 °C, Fig. S10). Based on the calculated rate constants (Table S4), the activation energy (Ea) was ca. 22 kcal mol−1, which is in the range of values reported in the literature for different types of organo-molybdenum epoxidation catalysts. A literature survey of Ea values for Cy epoxidation in the presence of Mo-based heterogenous catalysts revealed a value of 25.8 kcal mol−1 for a salcylidene salicyloyl hydrazinato dioxomolybdenum complex encapsulated in zeolite Y (temperature range 50–70 °C, O2 as oxidant) [41]. Broadening the literature survey to include any organo-molybdenum compounds as catalysts, the following Ea values were reported: 16.4–27.3 kcal mol−1 for dinuclear Schiff-base complexes (50–80 °C, TBHP as oxidant) [42,43], 11 and 20 kcal mol−1 for [MoO2(OSiPh3)2] and [MoO2(OSiPh3)2(2,2′-bipy)], respectively (35–70 °C, TBHP) [44], and 44.7 kcal mol−1 for the precatalyst [CpMo(CO)3CH3] (45–65 °C, TBHP) [45]. The influence of the type of solvent (α,α,α-trifluorotoluene (TFT), ethanol, acetonitrile and ethyl acetate) on the catalytic performance of 1 was studied at 70 °C (Fig. S9). The reaction kinetics was fastest for TFT as solvent; Cy conversion at 6 h/24 h followed the order TFT (81 %/100 %) > ethanol (45 %/92 %) > ethyl acetate (34 %/88 %) > acetonitrile (20 %/64 %). The slower reaction for ethanol and acetonitrile may be partly because these are coordinating solvents which, according to the mechanistic studies mentioned above, may compete with the reactants in the coordination to the molybdenum sites, retarding the overall epoxidation reaction. On the other hand, although no direct correlation could be established between solvent polarity and the reaction kinetics, one cannot exclude the possibility that competitive adsorption effects between reactants and solvents on the catalyst surface could influence the overall reaction process. Nevertheless, relatively high conversions were reached at 24 h using the biomass-derived solvents ethanol and ethyl acetate (88–92 %). Table S1 in the Supplementary data compares the catalytic results for 1 (TFT as solvent) with literature data for hybrid molybdenum oxide polymers possessing pyridine-type ligands, tested for Cy/TBHP epoxidation. The survey indicates that, in contrast to that verified for 1 (possessing a substituted 2,2′-bipy ligand), all polymeric hybrids bearing unsubstituted 2,2′-bipy exhibited homogeneous catalytic features, namely [Mo2O6(2,2′-bipy)] [46], [Mo3O9(2,2′-bipy)2] [46], [MoO3(2,2′-bipy)] [23] and {[MoO3(2,2′-bipy)][MoO3(H2O)]} n [31] (entries 2, 4, 8 and 9, respectively). The compounds which exhibited heterogeneous catalytic features were [(Mo2O6)(4,4′-bipy)] n [18], [Mo2O6(HpypzA)] [29], [MoO3(Hpytz)] [17] and [MoO3(Hpto)]·H2O [15] (entries 7, 10, 11 and 12, respectively). Based on the reported conversions and epoxide yields (and disregarding the different reaction conditions used), 1 performs relatively well as a catalyst. The highest epoxide yield within 6 h reaction was reported for [(Mo2O6)(4,4′-bipy)] n [18], which led to 99 % yield at rt and 2 h reaction, although high amounts of both catalyst and TBHP were used relative to the olefin (initial Mo:Cy:TBHP molar ratio = 1:36:64 vs. 1:100:153 for 1). In other work, heterogeneous catalysts synthesized via multistep procedures were reported, consisting of molybdenum complexes possessing pyridine-based ligands supported on functionalized supports such as surfactant templated silica and aluminosilicate, mixed metal oxides and polystyrene resin. Discarding the considerably different reaction conditions, these types of materials led to epoxide yields in the range of 66–100 % within 24 h (entries 13–18) [47–52]. The reaction of Cy with TBHP in the presence of 2 gave 98 % epoxide yield (with 100 % selectivity) at 6 h, 70 °C (Fig. 6, Table 1) and good oxidant consumption efficiency (0 %/5 % TBHP decomposition at 6 h/24 h, Fig. S7). Under identical reaction conditions, 2 was more active than the polymeric hybrid 1. Catalyst 2 partially dissolved in the reaction medium and led to a yellow-colored liquid phase, suggesting the presence of metal species in solution. A leaching test indicated that after separating the undissolved fraction of catalyst (at 30 min), the epoxidation reaction continued, following a similar kinetic profile to that for the normal catalytic test without catalyst filtration (Fig. 6). ICP-OES of the liquid phase of the reaction mixture indicated that ca. 42 mol% of the initial amount of molybdenum was dissolved (corresponding to ca. 0.42 mol% Mo based on initial amount of olefin). A catalytic test using 2 in an amount equivalent to 0.42 mol% Mo consistently led to a kinetic profile that was roughly coincident with that obtained under the typical reaction conditions with 1 mol% Mo (Fig. S8). Decreasing further the amount of catalyst from 0.42 to 0.1 mol% Mo led to slower reaction kinetics (97 % and 60 % conversion at 6 h, respectively). Increasing the temperature enhanced the reaction kinetics; conversion at 1 h increased from 68 % at 60 °C to ca. 100 % at 90 °C. The kinetic model, considering irreversible first order reactions (Section 4.5, Scheme S1), fitted reasonably well the experimental data for 2/Cy/TBHP at different temperatures (60, 70, 80 and 90 °C, Fig. S10b, d, f, and h). Based on the rate constants obtained (Table S4), the Ea was 16 kcal mol−1, which is in the range of literature values discussed above. The lower Ea for 2 than for 1 may be partly associated with the homogeneous catalytic nature of the former. Table S2 in the Supplementary data compares the catalytic results for 2 with literature data for di- and tetranuclear oxomolybdenum catalysts, tested for Cy/TBHP epoxidation. Based on the reported conversions and epoxide selectivities (and putting aside the different reaction conditions used), catalyst 2 performs relatively well. Catalyst stability tests were not reported for most of the compounds except for [Mo4O12(pzpy)4] (entry 2), which exhibited heterogeneous catalytic features and led to 55 % epoxide yield at 6 h/55 °C [34], and for dinuclear compounds that performed as homogeneous catalysts (entries 9, 10 and 11). To gain further insights into the stability of the 2/TBHP system, ATR FT-IR spectroscopic studies were carried out for the undissolved (2-TBHP) and soluble (2-TBHP-LP) fractions of recovered catalyst (Fig. S5 in the Supplementary data). The two solids exhibited somewhat comparable spectral features, while being different from the original catalyst. The morphology of 2 changed during the catalytic process from flake-like particles for 2 to spherical particles for the recovered solids (Fig. 2f–h). Thus, although compound 2 shows a remarkable enhancement of the epoxidation reaction kinetics (vs. 1), it undergoes a structural transformation, and the catalytic process is homogeneous. The species formed from 2 were not clearly identified; the IR bands above 1000 cm−1 (assigned to the organic ligand) were somewhat comparable to those for 2, while changes took place in the spectral region below 1000 cm−1, suggesting that 2 underwent alterations regarding the inorganic core comprising the metal–oxygen bonds (Fig. S5). 2.2.2 Catalytic features with H2O2 The Cy/H2O2 reaction in the presence of 1 gave 85 % conversion and 100 % epoxide selectivity, at 24 h, 70 °C (Table 1). The catalytic reaction was slower for the 1/H2O2 system than for the 1/TBHP one, which may be partly associated with the very distinct catalytic features of 1 with the different oxidants. While the system 1/TBHP presented heterogeneous catalytic features, 1 acted as a RISS catalyst with H2O2. Specifically, the initially insoluble solid catalyst was completely solubilized during the reaction, forming a homogeneous mixture (a yellow-colored solution containing the soluble active species). At the end of the reaction, the catalyst self-precipitated as an off-white solid (1-H2O2-run1) and the liquid phase was colorless (like the initial mixture). Iodometric titration indicated a negligible non-productive decomposition of H2O2 at 6 h reaction, but after 24 h the oxidant decomposition was 37 % (H2O2 can decompose to molecular oxygen plus water) (Fig. S7). A blank test without catalyst, at 70 °C, indicated no thermal decomposition of H2O2. Hence, besides epoxidation activity, the active species seemed to possess catalase-like activity with H2O2, (this was less important for TBHP as oxidant). With H2O2 as the limiting reactant (H2O2:Cy molar ratio = 0.75), the RISS features were preserved and 100 % conversion (based on the initial amount of oxidant) was reached at 24 h. Increasing the reaction temperature from 70 to 90 °C (using H2O2:Cy = 1.5) did not lead to a significant enhancement of Cy conversion (85 % and 88 %, respectively, at 24 h), which may be partly due to enhanced catalase-like activity at higher temperatures. The RISS catalyst was easily separated by centrifugation and reused at 70 °C. The RISS features and catalytic results were similar for the original and reused RISS catalyst (84–85 % conversion at 24 h; H2O2:Cy = 1.5) (Table 1). The PXRD patterns for the resultant self-precipitated solids (1-H2O2-run1 and 1-H2O2-run2, respectively) were comparable with those for the original catalyst 1, maintaining a good match with the simulated pattern calculated from the crystal structure data for [MoO3(DMB)] (Fig. 9 A). Moreover, the original and used catalysts exhibited comparable ATR FT-IR spectral features (Fig. 9B). While the crystalline structure was largely retained, SEM revealed a change in morphology from needle-like particles for 1 to aggregates of smaller particles for the self-precipitated solids (exemplified for 1-H2O2-run1 in Fig. 2d). Since the synthesis medium of 1 and the catalytic reaction medium are different, the catalyst recrystallization process is also likely to be different, thereby leading to a change in morphology. However, the PXRD and ATR FT-IR results for the catalyst used at 70 or 90 °C were similar, suggesting that the RISS catalyst was thermally stable (Fig. 9). To gain some insight into the nature of the soluble metal species, these were isolated at 6 h/70 °C, leading to a yellow-colored solid (1-H2O2-LP). A catalytic test with 1-H2O2-LP led to 48 % Cy conversion at 6 h, which is comparable with that for 1 (53 % conversion), confirming the catalytic role of 1-H2O2-LP. The characterization studies indicated that 1-H2O2-LP was different from 1 in terms of microstructure (different PXRD pattern with intense, narrow peaks, Fig. 9A(f)) and morphology (relatively large slab-like particles, Fig. 2e). The PXRD pattern of 1-H2O2-LP was tentatively indexed in the monoclinic system with space group P2 (full details, including Pawley whole-powder-pattern fitting, are given in the Supplementary data, Fig. S2). A search in the ICDD PDF-5+ database did not lead to any match with an existing and known phase. The ATR FT-IR spectra of 1 and 1-H2O2-LP were different in the spectral region below 1000 cm−1: the broad IR band for 1 in the range 600–680 cm−1 disappeared, suggesting that the degree of condensation decreased (less Mo-O-Mo bridges), and new, narrow bands appeared (Fig. 9B(f)). The pattern of new bands matches precisely that previously observed for oxodiperoxo complexes of the type [MoO(O2)2(L)], including those with L = 2,2′-bipy or substituted derivatives such as DBB [53]. Hence, 1-H2O2-LP is proposed to be the complex [MoO(O2)2(DMB)], with characteristic IR bands at 940 (ν(MoO)), 871 (sh) and 860 (ν(OO)), 531, 588 and 660 cm−1 (ν(Mo(O2)2)). Table S1 in the Supplementary data compares the catalytic results for 1 to literature data for molybdenum-based polymeric hybrids possessing pyridine-type ligands, tested for Cy/H2O2 epoxidation. Although comparably good results were reported for several hybrids, these performed as homogeneous catalysts. For example, with [MoO3(Hpto)]·H2O and [MoO3(4,4′-bipy)0.5] as catalysts [15,16], the homogeneous Cy reaction led to 81 % and 86 % epoxide yield at 24 h/70 °C (entries 20 and 26), respectively, which is similar to that for the RISS catalyst 1 (85 % yield). The Cy/H2O2 reaction in the presence of 2 gave 76 % conversion at 24 h/70 °C, and cyclooctene oxide was the only product (Table 1). In parallel to that observed for 1, the reaction kinetics was slower for 2/H2O2 than for 2/TBHP, which may be partly because 2/H2O2 exhibited catalase-like activity (24 %/49 % non-productive decomposition of the peroxide at 6 h/24 h, Fig. S7). Like 1/H2O2, the 2/H2O2 system presented RISS features, although the former led to higher oxidant efficiency (Fig. S7). The solid catalyst dissolved in the initial stage to give a yellow-colored solution, and at the end of the reaction it self-precipitated as an off-white solid (2-H2O2-run1). The RISS catalyst was reused, performing similarly; 76 % conversion at 24 h for the original and reused solids (Table 1). Characterization of the solids recovered from consecutive runs (2-H2O2-run1 and 2-H2O2-run2) showed that the morphology (SEM, Fig. 2i), crystalline structure (PXRD, Fig. 10 A) and chemical features (ATR FT-IR spectroscopy, Fig. 10B) of the original as-prepared catalyst 2 were retained. To gain insights into the types of active soluble species, these were isolated at 6 h reaction and characterized (2-H2O2-LP). The crystalline structure (PXRD, Fig. 10A) and morphology (SEM, Fig. 2j) of 2-H2O2-LP were different from those for 2, 2-H2O2-run1 and 2-H2O2-run2. The PXRD pattern of 2-H2O2-LP was tentatively indexed in the orthorhombic system with space group Pmn21 (full details, including Pawley whole-powder-pattern fitting, are given in the Supplementary data, Fig. S3). A search in the ICDD PDF-5+ database did not lead to any match with an existing and known phase. Paralleling that observed for 1, the changes observed in the ATR FT-IR spectrum of 2-H2O2-LP in the spectral region below 1000 cm−1 strongly suggest that the isolated solid is the oxodiperoxo complex [MoO(O2)2(DNB)], with characteristic bands at 533, 586, 659, 859 and 946 cm−1. The isolated compound 2-H2O2-LP was reused and led to 38 % Cy conversion at 6 h/70 °C, which is lower than that for 2 (68 % conversion), although still considerable. The differences in conversion between 2 and 2-H2O2-LP may be due to several factors, e.g., it cannot be guaranteed that all types of soluble metal species were isolated. Nevertheless, we may conclude that the RISS behavior of 1 and 2 with H2O2 as oxidant largely follows a sequence in which the original catalysts react with the oxidant to give soluble oxodiperoxo complexes which catalyze the epoxidation reaction, but which are reactive building blocks once the oxidant is consumed, leading to the reformation of 1 and 2, and their precipitation from the reaction mixture. To the best of our knowledge, 2 is the first example of a di- or oligomeric oxomolybdenum catalyst to display RISS behavior. Table S2 in the Supplementary data compares the catalytic results for 2 with literature data for di- and tetranuclear oxomolybdenum catalysts tested for the Cy/H2O2 reaction. Catalyst stability tests were generally not reported for the dinuclear compounds (when reported, catalysis was homogeneous) (entries 33–41). On the other hand, all reported tetranuclear compounds possessed phosphorus-containing ligands (entries 27–32), and led to up to 91 % epoxide yield, albeit using relatively high catalyst amounts (initial Mo:olefin molar ratio = 1:25 vs. 1:100 for 2 in the present work). Moreover, they were either unstable or no stability studies were reported [54]. The kinetic model, considering irreversible first order epoxidation reaction of Cy to CyO, fitted reasonably well the experimental data for 1/H2O2 and 2/H2O2 (Scheme S1, Fig. S11), giving a rate constant kCy of 0.1389 and 0.2644 h−1, respectively. These results were lower than those of the respective catalyst/TBHP systems, which is consistent with the slower reaction kinetics for H2O2 as oxidant. 2.3 Epoxidation of biobased olefins Hybrid 1 was further explored for the epoxidation of the biobased olefins DL-limonene (Lim), methyl oleate (MeOle) and methyl linoleate (MeLin), at 70 °C, using TBHP (Fig. 11 , Scheme 2 ). The superior oxidant efficiency of TBHP vs H2O2 (discussed above) makes the former an attractive oxidant. DL-Limonene is a racemic mixture of d-limonene and l-limonene, the former being the main component of some citrus rind oils and the latter being mainly found in pine needle oils [19,55]. The epoxidation of Lim gave the corresponding mono- and diepoxides, namely 1,2-epoxy-p-menth-8-ene (LimEp) and 1,2:8,9-diepoxy-p-menthane (LimDiEp), respectively, which have broad application profiles [56]. For example, LimEp is useful for the formulation of metal coatings, varnishes and printing inks [57], and for producing fragrances [58], pharmaceuticals [59], food additives and biodegradable polycarbonates (via copolymerization with CO2) [60], and polyesters via copolymerization with cyclic anhydrides [19]. On the other hand, LimDiEp is useful as a solvent, reactive diluent in epoxy resins, and for producing non-isocyanate polyurethanes (via LimDiEp/CO2 copolymerization) and thermosetting polymers [61–64]. The reaction of Lim in the presence of 1 gave LimEp and LimDiEp in 75 % and 25 % yield, respectively, at 24 h (100 % conversion; carbon balance closed at 100 %) (Fig. 11, Scheme 2). A 100 % carbon balance of Lim and its epoxides was reported in the literature for different molybdenum catalysts tested for Lim/TBHP conversion; e.g., the molybdenum oxide/organic cluster [Mo8O22(OH)4(DBB)4] led to 100 % selectivity of LimEp + LimDiEp (molar ratio of LimEp/LimDiEp = 3.5) at 98 % conversion, 55 °C/24 h (TFT as solvent) [65]. For 1, the selectivity to LimEp decreased from 100 % at 4 h to 75 % at 24 h (the respective cis and trans diastereoisomers were formed in roughly equimolar amounts), with the concomitant formation of LimDiEp. Nevertheless, LimEp was still the main product and 8,9-epoxy-p-menth-1-ene was not formed, suggesting a high regioselectivity towards the epoxidation of the endocyclic CC double bond (in relation to the exocyclic one). Based on these results and literature studies which suggested that olefin epoxidation may occur via attack of the nucleophilic olefin on an electrophilic O-atom of the active oxidizing species [66], the high regioselectivity may be partly explained by the internal CC bond being more electron rich and thus more reactive than the exocyclic CC bond. Based on the mechanistic proposal of Lim-LimEp-LimDiEp, a kinetic model considering irreversible first order reactions (Section 4.5, Scheme S1) was developed which fitted reasonably well the experimental data (Fig. S12). The rate constants of the consecutive reaction steps (k1,Lim and k2,Lim) were 0.4705 and 0.0407 h−1 (Table S5), which suggests that the subsequent step of the epoxidation of LimEp was slower than that of Lim conversion. This hypothesis was experimentally confirmed by performing a catalytic test with LimEp as substrate, under identical reaction conditions to those used for Lim at 24 h/70 °C. This led to 47 % LimEp conversion (100 % LimDiEp selectivity), which was less than half of that for Lim conversion. FAMEs are formed via (trans)esterification of vegetable oils, which are present in agricultural crops (e.g., olive, rapeseed, soybean oil) [57,67,68] and non-edible raw materials such as waste from the forest industry and waste cooking oil, or oil-producing microalgae [69]. MeOle and MeLin are the methyl esters of oleic and linoleic acids, respectively, being predominant in the fatty acid composition of many vegetable oils. The corresponding epoxides have widespread use in detergents and UV-curable coatings [70,71], as solvents in the cosmetic and pharmaceutical industries, as reactive diluents [72], PVC stabilizers and plasticizers [73,74], and as intermediates to produce biodegradable lubricants [75,76] and biobased polyols for synthesizing polyurethanes and polyesters [77,78]. The reactions of MeOle and MeLin, in the presence of 1, led to 79–81 % olefin conversion at 24 h, being very selective towards epoxides, and the carbon balances closed to ca. 100 %. With MeOle as substrate, methyl 9,10-epoxyoctadecanoate (MeOleEp) was formed with 100 % selectivity. A kinetic model, considering irreversible first order reactions (Section 4.5, Scheme S1), was developed which fitted reasonably well the experimental data (Fig. S13), giving a rate constant of 0.1230 h−1 (Table S5). With MeLin as substrate, the reaction products were mono- and diepoxides (Fig. 11, Scheme 2). Specifically, the monoepoxides (MeLinEp) were methyl 12,13-epoxy-9Z-octadecenoate and methyl 9,10-epoxy-12Z-octadecenoate), formed in equimolar amounts (no significant differences in reactivity were observed between the two internal CC bonds). The MeLinEp selectivity decreased from 100 % at 37 % conversion (2 h reaction) to 80 % at 79 % conversion (24 h), with the concomitant formation of methyl 9,10–12,13-diepoxyoctadecanoate (MeLinDiEp) isomers (20 % selectivity at 24 h). Accordingly, the overall reaction involved the series of steps MeLin-to-MeLinEp-to-MeLinDiEp. Based on this mechanistic proposal, a kinetic model, considering irreversible first order reactions (Section 4.5, Scheme S1), fitted reasonably well the experimental data (Fig. S14). The rate constants of the consecutive steps MeLin-to-MeLinEp-to-MeLinDiEp (k1,MeLin and k2,MeLin) were 0.1935 and 0.0579 h−1 (Table S5), which suggests that the second epoxidation step (MeLinEp-to-MeLinDiEp) is slower than MeLin conversion. These kinetic results, together with those for Lim, suggest that catalyst 1 is more effective for producing monoepoxides than diepoxides. Table S3 in the Supplementary data compares the catalytic results for 1 with literature data for oxomolybdenum polymeric hybrids possessing pyridine-type ligands, and different supported molybdenum complexes possessing pyridine-based ligands, tested as catalysts for the epoxidation of Lim and FAMES with TBHP. With Lim as substrate, only the homogeneous oxomolybdenum hybrid catalyst (DMA)[MoO3(cbpc)]·nH2O performed at the same level as 1 (100 % yield of the total epoxides at 75 °C/24 h), whereas the remaining catalysts led to the formation of byproducts (entry 5). Different families of materials consisting of molybdenum complexes bearing pyridine-type ligands supported on functionalized supports (e.g., surfactant-templated silica and mixed metal oxide nanoparticles) possessed activity for Lim epoxidation (entries 8–10); e.g., the complex [MoI2(CO)3(L)] supported on MCM-41 functionalized with a pyridylimine anchor ligand (L) led to 98 % selectivity towards LimEp plus LimDiEp at 98 % Lim conversion, 55 °C/24 h (entry 8) [50]. With MeOle as substrate, 1 led to 100 % MeOleEp selectivity at 81 % conversion. The literature survey revealed two polymeric hybrids that led to 100 % epoxide selectivity at ≥80 % MeOle conversion, namely [MoO3(Hpytz)] and [MoO3(Hpto)]·H2O, which presented heterogeneous catalytic features (entries 16 and 17) [15,17]. With MeLin as substrate, 1 and the other hybrids led to comparable conversions at 6 h/70 °C (59–68 %), although the previously studied hybrids led to byproduct formation (2–8 % yield of cyclization products at 24 h) (entries 18–21) [15,17,79]. To the best of our knowledge, there are no reports on heterogeneous catalysts consisting of supported molybdenum complexes bearing pyridine type ligands, tested for the epoxidation of MeOle and MeLin. 2.4 Reaction of isoeugenol Isoeugenol (4-propenyl-2-methoxyphenol) may derive from sawdust waste from oak and pine wood processing and is a representative compound of lignin-derived bio-oils [80–85]. The growing market envisaged for isoeugenol is of special interest to the flavor, fragrance, cosmetics, and pharmaceutical industries [86,87]. Isoeugenol can be converted to the neolignane, dehydrodiisoeugenol (DHIE), also known as Licarin A, which has important applications due to its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant and antibacterial activities [82,88,89]. Licarin A can be isolated from plants [90,91], but to satisfy growing needs, synthetic routes have been investigated such as the biocatalytic oxidative coupling reaction of isoeugenol using enzymes, bacteria and plant cell cultures [80,81,85,92–95]. The catalytic reaction of isoeugenol in the presence of 1 gave DHIE in 80 % selectivity at 40 % conversion, at 1 h/50 °C (Scheme 3 ). An increase in the reaction time from 1 h to 4 h led to 89 % conversion, but DHIE selectivity decreased to 40 %, and the carbon balance decreased from ca. 92 % to 47 %. Based on elemental analysis for carbon, the spent catalyst (after 4 h reaction) did not possess carbonaceous reaction products. Increasing the reaction temperature from 50 to 70 °C led to faster reaction (96 % conversion at 2 h/70 °C), but DHIE selectivity was only 30 %. The reaction without catalyst led to 4 % isoeugenol conversion at 1 h. In these systems, vanillin was not formed in measurable amounts, and the byproducts were not detected by GC–MS (possibly due to low volatility). According to the literature, the reaction of isoeugenol with TBHP may lead to polymeric (less volatile) byproducts [90,96], and this possibility cannot be ruled out in the present study. A literature survey for isoeugenol conversion reveals only two studies involving Mo-containing catalysts and TBHP, namely a molybdate intercalated Mg-Fe hydrotalcite [96], and a molybdate-incorporated hydrotalcite-type α-Ni(OH)2 [97]. However, in these two studies, DHIE formation was not reported (vanillin was formed, with guaiacyl ketone as byproduct). The conversion of isoeugenol to DHIE was reported using distinct systems (discussed in the Supplementary data). For example, a supported oxovanadium complex/H2O2 (24 wt% catalyst relative to isoeugenol) led to 49 % DHIE yield at 2 h/80 °C [98], CuFe2O4/TBHP led to 75 % DHIE yield at 50 °C/4 h [99], and Ag2O (catalyst:isoeugenol = 1:2) led to 40 % DHIE yield at 48 h/70–75 °C [100]. The mechanisms proposed for isoeugenol conversion to DHIE differ according to the type of metal (none involved molybdenum-based catalysts), oxidant, stoichiometric reactants, etc. Intermediates were not detected in measurable amounts for 1/isoeugenol/TBHP, making it difficult to establish a mechanism. Blank tests indicated that without TBHP or in the presence of the free ligand DMB (without molybdenum), no reaction had taken place by 1 h. Hence, the simultaneous presence of the molybdenum catalyst and the oxidant favored the conversion of isoeugenol to DHIE. On the other hand, a catalytic test was carried out for the 1/isoeugenol/TBHP system with a radical scavenger added initially to the mixture (in an equimolar amount relative to the substrate). This test led to comparable catalytic results (28 % DHIE selectivity at 87 % conversion) to those without radical scavenger (30 % yield at 96 % conversion), at 2 h/70 °C, suggesting that a free radical mechanism is not involved in the Mo-catalyzed conversion of isoeugenol to DHIE. One of the two studies mentioned above involving Mo-containing catalysts for isoeugenol oxidation, which led to vanillin (not DHIE), proposed a mechanism involving the interaction between a dioxomolybdenum moiety (Mo(O)2), isoeugenol (via the CC bond of the propenyl substituent) and TBHP, forming a 6-membered metallocycle possessing {MoOOC} bonds [97]. Based on these studies and the aforementioned mechanistic considerations with olefins as substrates, it may be postulated that species possessing a peroxomolybdenum moiety {MoOO} are formed and possibly play a catalytic role. Computational chemistry studies in the future may help to elucidate mechanistic details. 3 Conclusion The molybdenum oxide/bipyridine hybrid materials 1 and 2 of general formula [MoO3(L)] were synthesized by a green aqueous-based reflux methodology, starting from easily prepared dichlorodioxomolybdenum(VI) precursors, where the organic ligands themselves serve as structure directing agents. This is demonstrated by changing the substituent group of the organic ligand, which led to different structures, specifically, the chain-like polymer (1) with 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine, and a discrete multinuclear (di/tetranuclear) complex with 4,4′-dinonyl-2,2′-bipyridine. These hybrids acted as reaction induced self-separating (RISS) catalysts using H2O2 as oxidant and are, to the best of our knowledge, the first reported cases of Mo-based RISS epoxidation catalysts with bipyridine-type ligands. On the other hand, with tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant, the catalytic features of 1 and 2 were different. While 2 acted as a homogeneous catalyst, 1 presented heterogeneous (HE) catalytic features. Based on experimental and kinetic modeling studies (considering irreversible, first order reactions, which fitted reasonably well the experimental data under various conditions), the activation energy was slightly higher for 1 than 2 tested for the Cy/TBHP reaction. The hybrids were easily separated as RISS and/or HE catalysts and reused without significant loss of activity. Characterization studies suggested that the soluble active species involved in the RISS systems consisted of less condensed oxoperoxomolybdenum species, proposed to be complexes of the type [MoO(O2)2(L)], which were also capable of reforming the precipitated solid catalyst. The epoxidation of biobased DL-limonene (representative of the terpene family) and FAMEs was accomplished in selective fashions with the 1/TBHP system. Specifically, the reactions of Lim, methyl oleate and methyl linoleate gave epoxide yields at 24 h of 100 % for Lim and 79–81 % (100 % selectivity) for the FAMEs. Based on experimental and kinetic modeling studies for dienes, the formation of monoepoxides is faster than that of diepoxides. For the conversion of biobased isoeugenol to Licarin A, which has important anti-inflammatory, antioxidant and antibacterial properties, hybrid 1 led to 80 % selectivity at 40 % conversion (TBHP, 1 h, 50 °C). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of a molybdenum catalyst for this reaction (targeting Licarin A) and illustrates the potential of molybdenum oxide/organic hybrid catalysts to have a wide reaction scope. 4 Experimental section 4.1 Materials The following reagents and chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, unless otherwise stated, and used as received: (for synthesis) Molybdenum(VI) dichloride dioxide, DMB (99 %), DNB (97 %), anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (≥99.9 %), diethyl ether (≥99.8 %, Honeywell Riedel-de Haën), acetone (≥99.5 %, Honeywell Riedel-de Haën); (for the catalytic reactions) cis-cyclooctene (95 %, Alfa Aesar), methyl oleate (99 %), methyl linoleate (≥98 %), DL-limonene (>95 %, Merck), isoeugenol (>97 %, TCI), 5.5 M TBHP in decane (containing < 4 % water), 30 % aq. H2O2, anhydrous α,α,α-trifluorotoluene (≥99 %), acetonitrile (99.9 %, Panreac), ethanol (99.8 %, Honeywell Riedel-de Haën), ethyl acetate (99.7 %, Honeywell Riedel-de Haën), diethyl ether (99.8 %), pentane (≥99.5 %), 1,2-dichloroethane (≥99 %), methyl decanoate (99 %), and undecane (>99 %). 4.2 Characterization methods CHN elemental analyses were performed using a Leco TruSpec 630-200-200 analyzer (Leco, Saint Joseph, MI, USA). ICP-OES analyses for Mo were performed at the Central Analysis Laboratory, University of Aveiro, using a Horiba JobinYvon Activa M spectrometer (HORIBA Jobin Yvon Inc., Edison, NJ, USA). Prior to analysis, samples were digested using HF and HNO3, and microwave heating at 180 °C (for the procedure used, the detection limit for Mo was ca. 1 mg dm−3, and the experimental range of error was 10–20 %). Transmission FT-IR spectra of KBr pellets were recorded at room-temperature (rt) using a JASCO Jasco FT-IR 4X spectrophotometer equipped with a temperature-controlled DLaTGS detector and a high output ceramic source for maximum sensitivity (128 scans, resolution 4 cm−1, in the spectral range of 4000–350 cm−1). Attenuated total reflectance (ATR) FT-IR spectra were measured on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer equipped with a Specac® Golden Gate Mk II ATR accessory having a diamond top plate and KRS-5 focusing lenses (resolution 4 cm−1, 256 scans). FT-Raman spectra were recorded at rt in the range of 4000–50 cm−1 on a MultiRAM Bruker FT-Spectrometer equipped with a Nd:YAG laser with an excitation wavelength of 1064 nm (resolution 4 cm−1, 500 scans). Solid-state 13C{1H} CP MAS NMR spectra were recorded using a Bruker AVANCE III-400 MHz spectrometer with a 100.61 MHz ultra-shielded static magnetic field. The spectra were recorded with 3.2 µs 1H 90° pulses, 3.5 ms contact time, spinning rate of 10–12 kHz, and 4 s recycle delays. Chemical shifts are given in ppm relative to TMS. PXRD data were collected at rt on a Empyrean PANalytical diffractometer (Cu-Kα1,2 X-radiation (λ 1 = 1.540598 Å, λ 2 = 1.544426 Å); 45kv, 40 mA) in a Bragg-Brentano para-focusing opics configuration. The samples were prepared in a spinning flat plate holder and pre-scanned in the range 3–70° 2θ with steps of 0.026° and a counting time of 50 s per step. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed under air using a SETSYS 16 Evolution Setaram instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained on a Hitachi SU-70 SEM microscope equipped with a Bruker Quantax 400 detector operating at 15 kV. Samples were prepared by deposition on aluminum sample holders followed by carbon coating using an Emitech K 950 carbon evaporator. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at −196 °C using a Quantachrome instrument (automated gas sorption data using Autosorb IQ2; Anton Paar Group, Florida, FL, USA). The samples were pretreated at 120 °C for 3 h under vacuum (<4 × 10−3 bar). The total specific surface area (SBET) was calculated using the Brunauer, Emmett and Teller equation, and the pore size distribution curves were calculated by the BJH method (using the adsorption branch). 4.3 Catalyst synthesis 4.3.1 [MoO3(DMB)] (1) MoO2Cl2 (0.39 g, 1.95 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous THF (10 mL) under a nitrogen atmosphere, and the mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 20 min. Then, freshly sublimed (at 120 °C) DMB (0.74 g, 4.00 mmol) was added, and the mixture was left to stir at rt for 2 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, leaving a colorless solid. Milli-Q Water (20 mL) was then added, and the mixture was refluxed for 17 h under a nitrogen atmosphere, affording a white precipitate and a pink aqueous mother liquor (pH 1–3). The precipitate was isolated by centrifugation (6000 rpm, 20 min), washed with water (2 × 20 mL), acetone (2 × 20 mL), ethanol (2 × 20 mL), and diethyl ether (2 × 20 mL), and finally vacuum-dried for 2 h at rt. Reactions using TBHP as oxidant were carried out in a borosilicate reactor equipped with a PTFE valve for sampling. Initially, catalyst, solvent and substrate were added to the reactor containing a PTFE-coated magnetic stirring bar, which was then immersed in an oil bath heated to the desired reaction temperature. After stirring at 1000 rpm for 10 min, pre-heated TBHP was added to the reactor, and this moment was taken as the initial instant of the catalytic reaction. Control tests for the substrates with catalyst and without oxidant indicated negligible substrate conversion, i.e., the preheating procedure did not influence the initial activity. Other solvents were tested for the system 1/TBHP/70 °C, namely ethanol, ethyl acetate and acetonitrile. Catalytic reactions using H2O2 as oxidant were performed in tubular borosilicate batch reactors with pear-shaped bottoms (ca. 12 mL capacity), equipped with a vacuum PTFE valve for loading/emptying the reactor. Catalyst, substrate, solvent and H2O2 were loaded to the reactor (containing a magnetic stirring bar), which was then immersed in a temperature-controlled oil bath (70 °C). Separate catalytic experiments were carried out for each reaction time. The evolution of the reactions was monitored by analyzing freshly prepared samples by gas chromatography (GC), using a Varian 450 GC instrument equipped with a BR-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm; H2 as carrier gas) and a FID detector. The products were identified by GC mass spectrometry with GC-2010 Plus + GCMS-QP2010 Ultra (Shimadzu) instruments, equipped with a ZB-5 ms column (He as carrier gas). The quantification of reactants/products was based on calibrations; for the sets of substrates cis-cyclooctene (Cy)/DL-limonene (Lim)/isoeugenol (IE) and methyl oleate (MeOle)/methyl linoleate (MeLin), the internal standards used were undecane and methyl decanoate, respectively. The response factors of substrate/products were considered similar for each reaction system, which was checked for Cy/CyO and Lim/LimEp; for the remaining systems some products were commercially very expensive or hardly available, and thus not confirmed (nevertheless, the ratio of (total area of GC peaks)/(area of standard) was carefully monitored along time). Initial activities and turnover frequencies (TOFs) are based on olefin conversion at 1 h reaction and are expressed as mmolsubstrate gcat −1 h−1 (based on the mass of catalyst) and molsubstrate molMo −1 h−1 (based on the Mo loading), respectively. With IE as substrate, dehydrodiisoeugenol (DHIE) was formed, which was identified by GC–MS (the mass spectrum (Fig. S6) agrees with literature data [80,101]). Iodometric titrations were carried out to check the oxidant efficiency; specifically, catalytic tests were carried out with catalyst, Cy, oxidant and solvent, at 70 °C, and after 6 h or 24 h reaction, liquid samples were withdrawn for titration. The non-productive oxidant decomposition (to molecular oxygen) was calculated as the difference between the total amount of oxidant consumed (based on the titration) and the amount of oxidant consumed in the epoxidation reaction (based on GC). After the catalytic reactions, the undissolved solids were separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation (3500 rpm), thoroughly washed with diethyl ether, dried overnight under atmospheric conditions, and finally vacuum-dried (ca. 0.1 bar) at 60 °C for 1 h, giving the solids cat-oxidant-x, where cat = 1 or 2, oxidant = TBHP or H2O2, and x indicates either the run number (runi, i = 1, 2, 3) or reactions performed for 1 at 90 °C (x = 90C-runi). These recovered solids were characterized (by PXRD, ATR FT-IR spectroscopy and SEM) and used in subsequent batch runs; the initial Cy:oxidant:Mo mass ratio was kept constant in consecutive runs. For the systems 2/Cy/TBHP and 1 or 2)/Cy/H2O2, the dissolved metal species were isolated from the liquid phases (LP) at 6 h, and then washed and dried as described above for the undissolved solids, giving 2-TBHP-LP, 1-H2O2-LP and 2-H2O2-LP. To perform leaching tests (LT), the solid catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture, at the reaction temperature (70 °C), using a 0.2 μm PTFE membrane filter, and the filtrate was transferred to a separate pre-heated reactor and left to react at 70 °C with stirring; after a certain reaction time, the homogeneous mixture was analyzed by GC. 4.5 Kinetic models Based on the mechanistic proposals in Scheme S1, kinetic models were developed for each olefin substrate, considering perfectly stirred, isothermal batch reactors. The material balances for each species i were written according to equation (1): (1) d C i dt = r i where C i is the molar concentration of species i (M), t is the reaction time (h) and r i is the reaction rate of i . The models considered irreversible first order reactions (the ratio (total volume of reaction mixture)/(mass of catalyst) was kept constant for each substrate conversion system). For Cy, the kinetic model included Eqs. (1)-(3) with the rate constant k Cy (h−1): (2) d C Cy dt = - k Cy C Cy (3) d C CyO dt = k Cy C Cy For MeOle, the kinetic model included Eqs. (1), (4) and (5) with the rate constant k MeOle (h−1): (4) d C MeOle dt = - k MeOle C MeOle (5) d C MeOleEp dt = k MeOle C MeOle For MeLin, the kinetic model included Eqs. (1), (6)–(8) with the rate constants k 1,MeLin and k 2,MeLin (h−1): (6) d C MeLin dt = - k 1,MeLin C MeLin (7) d C MeLinEp dt = k 1,MeLin C MeLin - k 2,MeLin C MeLinEp (8) d C MeLinDiEp dt = k 2,MeLin C MeLinEp For Lim, the kinetic model included Eqs. (1), (9)-(11) with the rate constants k 1,Lim and k 2,Lim (h−1): (9) d C Lim dt = - k 1,Lim C Lim (10) d C LimEp dt = k 1,Lim C Lim - k 2,Lim C LimEp (11) d C LimDiEp dt = k 2,Lim C LimEp For all substrates, the equation systems were solved by numerical integration in Matlab (version R2024a), and the solution was refined by minimizing the objective function (Fobj ; Eq. (12)). (12) F obj = ∑ m ∑ n = 1 n p C m , n calc - C m , n exp 2 where C m , n calc and C m , n exp are the calculated and experimental concentration values, respectively, at each instant of time n, and for species m. The models developed fitted reasonably well the experimental data; the calculated and experimental curves are compared in Figs. S7–S11 for Cy with different oxidants and for each biobased olefin with TBHP. The rate constants (ki , h−1) were obtained from the fittings of the models to the experimental data (Tables S4 and S5). The activation energies (Ea) for the systems (1 or 2)/Cy/TBHP were calculated using the Arrhenius equation (Table S4). CRediT authorship contribution statement Diana M. coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum catalysts have been industrially recognized for decades for liquid phase epoxidation, which is an important chemical reaction process, since epoxides are used for many industrial applications. In this work, molybdenum oxide hybrid catalysts, prepared by a reflux hydrolysis methodology, performed effectively as heterogeneous catalysts or reaction-induced self-separating catalysts under mild reaction conditions; in the two cases, the catalyst separation and reuse are facilitated. Specifically, catalysts with the general formula [MoO3(L)], possessing polymeric chain-like (L = 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridine (1)) or oligomeric (L = 4,4′-dinonyl-2,2′-bipyridine (2)) structures comprising corner-sharing {MoO4N2} units, were synthesized and characterized by various complementary techniques (ATR FT-IR, Raman, 13C{1H} CP MAS NMR spectroscopy, PXRD, SEM, TGA, elemental analysis, ICP-OES and N2 sorption isotherms). Small chemical differences in the organic synthesis precursor had important structure directing effects on the type of hybrid material formed. The hybrids promoted olefin epoxidation with H2O2 or tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) as oxidant. For example, 1 catalyzed the conversion of biobased olefins (70 °C) and lignin-based isoeugenol (50 °C) with TBHP to useful bioproducts, in heterogeneous phase, leading to an epoxide yield of 100 % for DL-limonene (3:1 M molar ratio of 1,2-epoxy-p-menth-8-ene to 1,2:8,9-diepoxy-p-menthane), 81 % epoxide yield for fatty acid methyl esters, and 80 % Licarin A selectivity at 40 % isoeugenol conversion. For dienes (DL-limonene, methyl linoleate), kinetic modelling studies suggested that the formation of the monoepoxides was faster than that of diepoxides, accounting for enhanced monoepoxide selectivity.
